title: Bruised fruit grower Costa in hefty downgrade
text:
The drought has forced fruit and vegetable grower Costa Group into another hefty profit downgrade with a heavily-discounted capital raising of $176 million to shore up its balance sheet so it can ride through an extended downturn.

Costa Group chief executive Harry Debney said late on Monday that the company had previously signalled that it potentially faced further downside in performance across its mushrooms, raspberries and blueberries operations, and that had eventuated.

"In addition, the prolonged and extreme dry and hot conditions across many of our operations are manifesting in actual and projected deterioration in fruit sizing and yield in citrus, avocados and blueberries, exacerbating price declines,'' Mr Debney said.

The company has also decided to put on hold a planned 10 hectare expansion of a glasshouse project for tomato growing at Guyra in New South Wales because of concerns over water security issues.

Mushrooms are one of the crops under pressure at Costa Group. Rebecca Hallas

Mr Debney said the calendar year 2019 forecast was for all categories of produce apart from tomatoes to deliver results below expectations.
description: Costa Group's $176 million raising is at a heavy discount as the fruit and vegetable grower sounded yet another profit warning amid a worsening drought.
